articles.title: Our sister died because of our mum's cancer conspiracy theories, say brothers - BBC
articles.summary: 'Our sister died of cancer because of our mum's conspiracy theories' Social media investigations correspondent Gabriel and Sebastian Shemirani watched with concern as their mother Kate rose to notoriety during the pandemic, eventually getting struck off as a nurse for promoting misinformation about Covid-19. articles.title: WHO Eyes Emerging COVID-19 Variant - Medscape
articles.summary: WHO Eyes Emerging COVID-19 Variant A new variant of COVID-19 is on the rise globally, but the overall risk to the public remains low, according to a report from the World Health Organization (WHO). Although the variant, NB. 1.8.1, is increasing in proportion to other circulating variants, routine clinical surveillance data have not yielded any signs of increased severity associated...

articles.title: Guest column | Ask a Vet: Why does my pet lick me so much? - The Washington Post
articles.summary: Ask a Vet: Why does my pet lick me so much? And is it safe to let them do it? (Hannah Good/The Washington Post) Q: Why does my pet lick me — and is it safe to let them do it? A: Dogs and cats may lick humans to show empathy or affection — or simply to get your attention.

articles.title: Column | We asked an oncologist: Should we worry about endocrine disruptors? - The Washington Post
articles.summary: As an oncologist, here’s what I wish people knew about endocrine disruptors What to know about everyday exposures to BPA, PFAS and phthalates. (Washington Post illustration; iStock) Column by Mikkael A. Sekeres, MD If you’ve been on social media lately, chances are you’ve heard about endocrine disruptors. People say they can interfere with your hormones, leading to serious health conditions.
